history.content:
Interesting, I was just looking into it last night . 

the first question you have to ask yourself is if you want to have a B.S. on your degree or B.A.

I think if you are in Engineering do EECS/Engineering math & stats. This a pretty good combo. You can cross pollinate EE126.

if you are not , do applied math and minor in cs. However this combo will not get in some great classes to prepare for machine learning like 127 & 126.

——————————

both ways are pretty good. Math by itself is not enough you need to cross pollinate it with something else. Since this is the EECS/CS piazza I assume you want to do cs as well.

I met a lot of applied math at Berkeley (ima a senior now) but no Engineering math & stats so you will be unique for jobs in the future.

I'm thinking about majoring in one of the two, but which one is seen as more legitimate to grad schools and research capability? There isn't too much info on Engineering Math and Stats, and I'm not sure if it is seen as "less math-rigorous and more engineering" oriented than Applied math, even though their prereqs are almost the same. Anyone have any info on the difference between the two?
history.subject: Is there any difference between Applied Math and Engineering Math and Stats?
